job_title: Peer Research Mentor in Des Moines, IA
pros: The bosses are very nice and understanding
cons: there are no cons to this job

job_title: Photo Bureau Manager in Des Moines, IA
pros: This is probably one of the better on campus jobs. Ties in well with Advertising and Marketing degrees.
cons: Difficult to manage other student interns. If you have trouble managing your peers this is not for you.

review_title: Sexist. Stuck in the dark ages
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, IA
pros: Amazing people to work with. Great flexible work environment and time off. Good 401K matching.
cons: Deeply sexist work culture with no respect from the President who treats his employees like military. There is no growth opportunity and very little appreciation of the very hard work that staff put in. Now working at another organization I realize how Drake takes advantage of its employees by paying them very low and expecting way beyond what should be legal.

job_title: Student Worker in Des Moines, IA
pros: Flexibility for students who need time
cons: Minimum wage suck, Make more at McDonalds

job_title: Editor-In-Chief in Des Moines, IA
pros: I enjoyed the leadership team with the BSC, and the freedom that comes from leading an RSO - plenty of flexibility with my advisor and the ability to get funding in order to get things done. A fun group to work with, on a campus that I care deeply about.
cons: The pay is horrible. Federal minimum wage for a leadership position with a university magazine. It's embarrassing that the university still underpays its students to such an extent. Stop relying on your students' activity's fee to pay your students. The amount of revenue that student organizations accumulate for the university from attracting prospective students is enormous, and its criminal that you don't compensate student leaders and workers for their labor. A college is nothing without its student orgs and clubs.

job_title: Head Start in Des Moines, IA
pros: You work for Drake, which by itself sounds great.
cons: You actually work for head start who follow their own set of rules. I was told “XYZ” during the interview process, but in reality the job is that of a kitchen worker with no breaks, who is on call to sub at any location with no notice. They advertise and promote the job as a teacher associate, but you spend your time making grilled cheese. You have ZERO breaks thought out the day. Zero. You are expected to answer your phone at all hours of the night and weekend. When I didn’t answer my phone, my supervisor chewed me out. She blew up my phone with texts and voicemails. The morale is terrible. Everyone gossips about everyone else. They falsify records that are supposed to be “legal”. I could not leave that job fast enough, it was a lie from the start but when you have a supervisor whose go to tactics are that of bullying and lying and literally whispering behind your back - it screams toxic environment. Which is so so sad for the little preschoolers they are supposed to be serving.

job_title: Faculty in Des Moines, IA
pros: Lots of scholarship to attract students
cons: Very RACIST place. 99% white students and no diversity. White faculty tends to dominate in Math/CS. You have to follow their examples, no matter how much experience you have. Non-White faculty are like "tokens" for display. Racial incidents are handled via a script. Townhalls for white, black and staff. Nothing constructive. If you believe in equal opportunity, this is not it.

job_title: Undergraduate Student in Des Moines, IA
pros: Great social atmosphere on campus. Lot's of ways to get involved.
cons: over working culture... "Drake Busy"

job_title: HVAC Engineer in Des Moines, IA
pros: Awesome atmosphere and good people to work with.
cons: Pay is a bit low.

job_title: Help Desk Technician in Des Moines, IA
pros: Short walk and flexible hours as a student
cons: Bad pay, end users typically annoying

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hoffman Estates, IL
pros: Was a student-athlete over the course of my 4 years while studying psychology
cons: Very rigorous school but worth it

review_title: Administrative assistant for the school of education

pros: Flexible, great environment, room to grow.
cons: not great pay, no bennefits.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Des Moines, IA
pros: flexilble hours when working at the desk
cons: very monotonous work that is draining

job_title: IT Infrastructure Specialist in Des Moines, IA
pros: Flexible, understanding environment that requires very few formalities. Easy dress code.
cons: Low pay for the job. Unsure job security related to school enrollment numbers. No raises in sight.

job_title: Assistant Director, Enterprise Architect in Des Moines, IA
pros: I love working for Drake. The community, culture, and surrounding area are incredible. I truely like going into work each day. Very generous dedicated vacation and separate sick time, plus paid holidays (including the time between Christmas and the New Year!
cons: As Drake is a Not-For-Profit Higher Eduction institution, salaries are typically lower than For-Profit jobs.

job_title: Employee in Des Moines, IA
pros: Co-workers and students are the reason I stay. Paid time off is great! Flexibility of working hours is appreciated.
cons: Low pay, low morale, health benefits getting worse every year (less coverage, higher deductibles and rates). Employees have to pay an obnoxious amount to park in Drake owned lots. All other universities in the area offer free parking to faculty and staff. There are very few spaces to park in the street that aren't already taken up by residential students, so you're forced to purchase a parking pass. No raises in at least two, maybe three years.

job_title: Laboratory Instructor in Des Moines, IA
pros: The benefits are good overall.
cons: Turn over is extremely high due to the lack of monetary compensation.

job_title: Assistant Coach in Des Moines, IA
pros: The people at the university
cons: Low pay and out of touch administration

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Des Moines, IA

cons: There was no cons to this job.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Des Moines, IA
pros: Nice people to be honest

job_title: Head Coach in Des Moines, IA
pros: This is a university with the best people. Truly!
cons: Salaries are low compared to other universities.

job_title: Student Assistant in Des Moines, IA
pros: Inclusive, Diverse, Accountable, and was flexible with scheduling
cons: I thought this was a work study but was not allowed to do homework at the front desk

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, IA

review_title: Office of Admissions at Drake University
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, IA
pros: Flexibility, highly-engaged team members, opportunities to plan and execute events.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: easy to do work study
cons: none that i can think of

job_title: ** Prefer Not to Say ** in Des Moines, IA
pros: This position was rewarding and a good start for someone pursuing a career in law enforcement.  I gained a vast array of experience and training.  Had the ability to work with students and provide a safe learning environment. Over time the department made some minor improvements with equipment and vehicles.  This position has low supervision with a high level of responsibility.
cons: This University does not know how to manage money properly and is ran by socialist left swinging liberals. Every year the non-exempt employees are given budget excuses on why the pay won't increase. The rare occasions it did improve it was no more than 2%. Meanwhile,  the university continues to build new buildings and invest in pointless landscaping projects.  The health benefits are, and there is no incentive to stay for an extended period other than your children can go to college for free.  This particular department also has experienced massive turnover over the years.  The burden on the other employees to cover the shifts with minimum staffing is burning staff out quickly.  It is common practice forcing employees into 12 hours shifts and overtime.   The department suffers from low morale and most likely will never improve.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Des Moines, IA
pros: Great team atmosphere and supportive management.
cons: Would love to see pay increases.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Des Moines, IA
pros: Get to meet a lot of people, get used to crisis management
cons: Poor management, they hardly are trained.

job_title: Pharmacy Student in West Des Moines, IA
pros:
Small class size
Tailored educational experience
cons:
Cost
Difficult to find online classes at times

review_title: Small community feel makes Drake a great place to work
job_title: in Des Moines, IA
pros: Drake University has a great benefit package for all full-time faculty and staff. Tuition reimbursements, great health/dental plans, and vacation time are some of the highlights. It's a small campus where everyone knows everyone and I find there is a lot of interactivity between departments. Human Resources offers plenty of learning and development opportunities as well.
cons:
Because the school is so small a lot of staff rely on one another. If one department falls short many other departments are affected. We have been dealing with a lot of technical issues that keep reoccuring, unfortunately it's an issue stemming from just a small portion of our staff. 
To correspond with the statements about benefits above, if there's one thing I wish I could benefit more from would be a more competitive salary.

review_title: Drake IT - Dishonest top administration, Leaders lack integrity
job_title: Sys Administrative in Des Moines, IA
pros:
Good work life balance
Decent benefits package but not great
Expectations with IT are low
cons: There's a bunch of new leaders here at drake and everyone wants to make their mark. Top level decisions are made either in complete secrecy, or with "governance" which means we'll gather input but do whatever we think is good. The liars are constantly promoted here. Hard work is rewarded by more hard work and zero promotional opportunities and even pay cuts for "parity" with your job. Drake charges a HUGE sum to go here: WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO!?? Sure, I got raises but nothing to keep up with inflation. There is no appreciation for IT employees: we are all counted as expendable.

job_title: Network Engineer II in Des Moines, IA
pros: On the right track! The leadership in IT understand what it takes to run a successful operation. They are moving toward a model where people are rewarded for hard work and those that are overpaid are being tended to. Salary is extremely competitive, even with private sector here in DSM. Work/Life balance is second to none.
cons: End users sometimes struggle to understand all that is required to keep an institution up and running as far as technology goes. Lot of complaining but not a lot of people interested in stepping up to offer ideas and suggestions.

review_title: IT management could hold educate others
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, IA
pros: Drake IT does a tremendous job of promoting life-work balance. As you would expect, training is readily available, and the perk of taking classes at the University is a glorious benefit. All of the management during my time there was great to work with, always having your back and helping you get better at your job.
cons: There was a real challenge getting faculty to understand that you were there to help, and it was your job to work on their equipment. Asking permission to work on a computer that you had just days before handed to a professor takes a certain patience not all could handle.

job_title: Client Services in Des Moines, IA
pros: There are some non-management staff that does have an interest in making the environment better but they are far and few between. Most hang out for a paycheck and keep their head down.
cons: The new CITO has transformed the place into a sweat shop. The salaries are lower than anywhere in town which in the Des Moines market, guarantees you will get staff who are second-tier. The expectation is that you will work well beyond your 40 hours.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, IA
pros:
Most people are there because they truly do care about student learning
I worked under great management
Some flexibility in schedule (if you're hourly)
Benefits package
Winter break off
Hub of election events
cons:
Salary is not competitive at all
Not very innovative place to work for
We've been trying to implement a new curriculum for years, with no luck due to bureaucracy; it takes too long to make change happen
Lack of ethnic diversity + mentorship

job_title: Support in Des Moines, IA
pros: Small campus. Close to downtown, restaurants, shops.
cons: There is no money for salaries but money to buy whatever upper Administration wants and if it isn’t what they like, they buy something else. Your money is spent on unnecessary items to impress people and bump up an ego for the latest and greatest tech toys. Traveling is at its best,including spouses. The Old Main offices have very high turnover of staff.  Raises at 1.5 percent only. Overworked and understaffed.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Des Moines, IA
pros: Co-workers and students are nice
cons: Low wages. No pay increases for next three years. Everyone gets same raise when they are given; normally between 1-2 %, and those are also the years they increase insurance premiums. Parking rates increase yearly. My take home pay goes down yearly.  Morale is extremely low. Job titles don’t match job description so they can pay less. Feel extremely undervalued.

review_title: Best student job at Drake University, especially if you love sports
job_title: Junior Intramural Supervisor in Tempe, AZ
pros:
- Opportunity to learn leadership and conflict management skills.
- A great way to earn money officiating and supervising sports you love. Even if you don't know a particular sport, there are paid training sessions to help you officiate effectively.
- Great team to work with!
cons: - Night shifts can be particularly brutal at times. Some sports might have games that end as late as 10.30pm and cleaning up and keeping the equipment back could take another 30-60 minutes. This however are quite rare.

review_title: The people you served and helped were wonderful, the people leading the pack were self-absorbed.
job_title: in Des Moines, IA
pros: Great high education institution. Wonderful facilities and benefits.
cons: Very senior management is out of touch with reality and does little to trust those who work for them that know more than they do. Second -guessing and playing people against each other wastes time and energy and ultimately does not serve the institution or the students.

review_title: I worked at Drake University as a student worker in the Residence Halls.
job_title: Residence Hall Receptionist in Des Moines, IA
pros: Small school. Tight community. Friendly faces. Freedom to study for exams or socialize with friends (old & new).... Plus, you're working at home. So you can wear pj's to work. Need I say more?
cons: Minimum wage. Repetitive work. Possible late/overnight shifts that can be boring and require obscene amounts of caffeine consumption.

review_title: Below Average Pay. Impossible Advancement. Just ok.

pros:
Tuition Reimbursement
Insurance mostly paid
Easy workload
Caring Coworkers
cons:

Job is boring and too easy

job_title: Lab Tutor in Des Moines, IA
pros: As a lab tutor, we had consistent hours, a lot of autonomy, and a nice study space to work in. We could study when we had downtime.
cons: University wages are low, essentially a dead end job, no opportunities for advancement, students come in waves.

job_title: Student Ambassador in Des Moines, IA
pros: I love the work environment, everyone is friendly in the office. It is easy to develop relationships and find mentors within the office. In addition, ambassadors are given a lot of agency and leeway when it comes to tasks.
cons: Giving tours in below zero is probably the most difficult thing about the job. Other than that, the job is really the best work study job on campus.

job_title: Associate Professor in Des Moines, IA
pros: Students are great.  Administration is good.  Good resources for conference attendance, faculty development.  Stability.  Community respects the institution.
cons: You have to enjoy being on your own.  You will not receive mentorship or appreciation.  Everyone works in isolation.

job_title: Gallery Assistant in Des Moines, IA
pros: Friendly Supervisors, getting to work with friends, flexible hours
cons: extremely low pay, 20 hours a week maximum

review_title: A great school for a great future.

cons: There have been some shakeups in terms of computer support, but it appears have gotten much better over the last year or so.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Des Moines, IA
pros: DU treats its adjunct instructors quite well. They offer paid opportunities to present research to the faculty ($350) for feedback.
cons: As with every other adjunct situation, compensation is very low: $1000 per credit hour. They only offer work by the semester.
